Automation does not imply lack of =
human involvement - perhaps "full
automation" does.  But we never used that=
 term.

The most effective and common form of automation is one in which th=
e
machine (or computer) and the human each perform the tasks that they
do b=
est or more effectively.

Unless it's misused, automation is a good thing -=
 a VERY good thing.

The first benefit of automation is that it frees human=
 beings from
performing aspects of a given task that don't require their
in=
telligence, creativity, and insight and allows them to focus on the
aspects=
 that do.

A second benefit of automation is that it allows you to do thing=
s that
 would be impossible or impractical to do manually and allows human
=
beings to reach well beyond what they could do on their own.  Some
people c=
all this IA (Intelligence Amplification).

We designed Agitator to automate=
 the aspects of testing that would
benefit from automation and, VERY intent=
ionally, did NOT automate the
parts that REQUIRE human intelligence, creati=
vity, and understanding
to have any meaning (e.g. the creation of test asse=
rtions).

Different people prefer different levels of automation for differ=
ent
tasks (e.g. my mother still likes to make home-made fettuccine without
=
a pasta maker - mixing them and cutting them by hand.  Enjoying the
process=
 and liking the fact that each strand is a little different.
Takes ~2hrs th=
ough. Other use a Cuisinart and a pasta machine.  Others
buy them at Safewa=
y :-)).

When it comes to testing, including test creation, my belief and
e=
xperience is that the *right* *level* of automation is not only
acceptable =
and desirable, but necessary.

Alberto
